article.title: Commodore_1570
article.paragraph: unreferencedJune 2009yesImage:Commodore 1570 01.JPGright300pxTheCommodore 1570is a 5"floppy diskdrive for theCommodore 128home computerhome/personal computer. It is a single-sided, 170-KB version of theCommodore 1571, released as a stopgap measure whenCommodore Internationalwas unable to provide large enough quantities of 1571s due to a shortage of double-sided drive mechanisms (supplied from an outside manufacturer). Like the 1571, it can read and write bothGroup Code RecordingGCRandModified Frequency ModulationMFMdisk formats.The 1570 utilizes a 1571 logic board in a cream-coloredCommodore 1541original-1541-like case with a drive mechanism similar to the 1541's except that it was equipped with track-zero detection. Like the 1571, its built-in DOS provides a data burst mode for transferring data to the C128 computer at a faster speed than a 1541 can. ItsRead-only memoryROMalso contains some DOS bug fixes that didn't appear in the 1571 until much later. The 1570 can read and write all single-sidedCP/M operating systemCP/M-format disks that the 1571 can access.

Although the 1570 is compatible with theCommodore 64, the C64 isn't capable of taking advantage of the drive's higher-speed operation, and when used with the C64 it's little more than a pricier 1541. Also, many early buyers of the C128 chose to temporarily make do with a 1541 drive, perhaps owned as part of a previous C64 setup, until the 1571 became more widely available.citation neededNovember 2014
